newsitem.title: GERMANY: Beta Systems IPO boosted by retail buying.
newsitem.headline: Beta Systems IPO boosted by retail buying.

text.p: The share price of Beta Systems Software AG more than doubled on Monday after an initial public offering, fuelled by German retail investors thirsting for a hot technology stock.
Issued at 100 marks, Beta's shares climbed to a high of 215 before closing bourse trading at 206 marks.

"There's a scarcity of growth technology stocks in Germany," said Rennie Miller, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, the IPO's global coordinator. "The German retail market has been keen to buy into technology issues, but they're few and far between."
Beta benefited from last fall's successful launch of Deutsche Telekom AG shares, he said.
Telekom issued 713 million shares after a massive marketing campaign that brought thousands of retail investors into the stock market.
Since then, Telekom shares have climbed 47 percent to 42 marks.
Beta, a 13-year-old developer of software for IBM Corp mainframes, issued 980,000 shares and had 147,000 more in reserve for a "greenshoe option" if demand was high.
About 70 percent of the issue represented a capital increase aimed at financing overseas growth and acquisitions, especially in the United States.
Beta had 1996 sales of 56.5 million marks. DMG forecast sales would rise to 73 million marks ($42 million) in 1997, 93.3 milllion in 1998 and 117 million in 1999.
DMG also predicted earnings per share would rise from 5.20 marks this year to 6.70 marks in 1998 and 9.40 marks in 1999.

Beta previously reported that over the last five years sales have increased about 30 percent each year while operating profit had risen about 62 percent annually. The IPO left 44 percent of the company's equity in the hands of founders Alfred Tachnitz and William P. Schmidt.
-- Neal Boudette, Bonn Newsroom, +49-228 26097150 ($ = 1.739 German Marks)
